Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Dexamethasone as a Local Anaesthetic Adjunct in Lower Limb Surgery

Intervention.evidence: comparing intravenous and perineural dexamethasone as local anaesthetic adjuncts

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the duration of analgesia, measured from the block's performance to the first analgesic request.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods varied across trials.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding of outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians was inconsistently reported.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Nine trials with 546 patients were included.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Perineural dexamethasone increased the duration of analgesia from 19.54 to 22.27 hours, with a mean difference of 2.73 hours (95% CI 1.07 to 4.38; p = 0.001; IÂ² = 87).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were not consistently reported.
